column1: [Illustration]           On the bridge one leap he makes;           Crash!
column6: While the scared boys were skedaddling,           Down the brook two geese came paddling.
column7: [Illustration]           On the legs of these two geese,           With a death-clutch, Buck did seize; [Illustration]           And, with both geese _well in hand_,           Flutters out upon dry land.
column8: [Illustration]           For the rest he did not find           Things exactly to his mind.
column9: [Illustration]           Soon it proved poor Buck had brought a           Dreadful belly-ache from the water.
column11: She rises           Fully equal to the crisis;           With a hot flat-iron, she           Draws the cold out famously.
column12: [Illustration]           Soon 'twas in the mouths of men,           All through town: "Buck's up again!"
column13: *       *       *       *       *           This was the bad boys' third trick,           But the fourth will follow quick.
column15: AN old saw runs somewhat so:           Man must learn while here below.--           Not alone the A, B, C,           Raises man in dignity;           Not alone in reading, writing,           Reason finds a work inviting;           Not alone to solve the double           Rule of Three shall man take trouble:           But must hear with pleasure Sages           Teach the wisdom of the ages.
column16: [Illustration]           Of this wisdom an example           To the world was Master Laempel.
column17: For this cause, to Max and Maurice           This man was the chief of horrors;           For a boy who loves bad tricks           Wisdom's friendship never seeks.
column18: With the clerical profession           Smoking always was a passion;           And this habit without question,           While it helps promote digestion,           Is a comfort no one can           Well begrudge a good old man,           When the day's vexations close,           And he sits to seek repose.--           Max and Maurice, flinty-hearted,           On another trick have started;           Thinking how they may attack a           Poor old man through his tobacco.
column19: Once, when Sunday morning breaking,           Pious hearts to gladness waking,           Poured its light where, in the temple,           At his organ sate Herr Laempel, [Illustration]           These bad boys, for mischief ready,           Stole into the good man's study,           Where his darling meerschaum stands.
column20: This, Max holds in both his hands; [Illustration]           While young Maurice (scapegrace born!)
column21: Climbs, and gets the powderhorn,           And with speed the wicked soul           Pours the powder in the bowl.
column25: [Illustration]           Laempel closes the church-door,           Glad to seek his home once more; [Illustration]           All his service well got through,           Takes his keys, and music too,           And his way, delighted, wends           Homeward to his silent friends.
column26: Full of gratitude he there           Lights his pipe, and takes his chair.
column28: he says, "no joy is found           Like contentment on earth's round!"
column32: The pipe is burst,           Almost shattered into dust.
column33: Coffee-pot and water-jug,           Snuff-box, ink-stand, tumbler, mug,           Table, stove, and easy-chair,           All are flying through the air           In a lightning-powder-flash,           With a most tremendous crash.
column34: [Illustration]           When the smoke-cloud lifts and clears,           Laempel on his back appears;           God be praised!
column35: still breathing there,           Only somewhat worse for wear.
column36: [Illustration]           Nose, hands, eyebrows (once like yours),           Now are black as any Moor's;           Burned the last thin spear of hair,           And his pate is wholly bare.
column37: Who shall now the children guide,           Lead their steps to wisdom's side?
column38: Who shall now for Master Laempel           Lead the service in the temple?
column39: Now that his old pipe is out,           Shattered, smashed, _gone up the spout_?
column40: [Illustration]           Time will heal the rest once more,           But the pipe's best days are o'er.
column41: *       *       *       *       *           This was the bad boys' fourth trick,           But the fifth will follow quick.
column43: IF, in village or in town,           You've an uncle settled down,           Always treat him courteously;           Uncle will be pleased thereby.
column45: Any errand I can do you?"
column46: Fetch whatever he may need,--           Pipe to smoke, and news to read;           Or should some confounded thing           Prick his back, or bite, or sting,           Nephew then will be near by,           Ready to his help to fly;           Or a pinch of snuff, maybe,           Sets him sneezing violently:           "Prosit!
column51: Or he comes home late, perchance:           Pull his boots off then at once,           Fetch his slippers and his cap,           And warm gown his limbs to wrap.
column52: Be your constant care, good boy,           What shall give your uncle joy.
column55: See now how they tried their wits--           These bad boys--on Uncle Fritz.
column56: What kind of a bird a May-           Bug was, _they_ knew, I dare say; [Illustration]           In the trees they may be found,           Flying, crawling, wriggling round.
column57: [Illustration]           Max and Maurice, great pains taking,           From a tree these bugs are shaking.
column58: [Illustration]           In their cornucopiae papers,           They collect these pinching creepers.
column59: [Illustration]           Soon they are deposited           In the foot of uncle's bed!
column60: [Illustration]           With his peaked nightcap on,           Uncle Fritz to bed has gone;           Tucks the clothes in, shuts his eyes,           And in sweetest slumber lies.
column63: come the Tartars           Single file from their night quarters.
column64: [Illustration]           And the captain boldly goes           Straight at Uncle Fritzy's nose.
column68: [Illustration]           Uncle, wild with fright, upspringeth,           And the bedclothes from him flingeth.
column70: he seizes two more scape-           Graces from his shin and nape.
column71: [Illustration]           Crawling, flying, to and fro,           Round the buzzing rascals go.
column72: [Illustration]           Wild with fury, Uncle Fritz           Stamps and slashes them to bits.
column74: all gone by           Is the May bug's deviltry.
column75: [Illustration]           Uncle Fritz his eyes can close           Once again in sweet repose.
column76: *       *       *       *       *           This was the bad boys' fifth trick,           But the sixth will follow quick.
column78: EASTER days have come again,           When the pious baker men           Bake all sorts of sugar things,           Plum-cakes, ginger-cakes, and rings.
column79: Max and Maurice feel an ache           In their sweet-tooth for some cake.
column80: [Illustration]           But the Baker thoughtfully           Locks his shop, and takes the key.
column81: [Illustration]           Who would steal, then, _this_ must do:           Wriggle down the chimney-flue.
column83: There come the boys, my Jiminy!
column84: Black as ravens, down the chimney.
column86: into a chest they drop,           Full of flour up to the top.
column87: [Illustration]           Out they crawl from under cover           Just as white as chalk all over.
column88: [Illustration]           But the cracknels, precious treasure,           On a shelf they spy with pleasure.
column91: down they go-- [Illustration]           Schwapp!--into a trough of dough!
column92: [Illustration]           All enveloped now in dough,           See them, monuments of woe.
column93: [Illustration]           In the Baker comes, and snickers           When he sees the sugar-lickers.
column97: [Illustration]           There's the oven, all red-hot,--           Shove 'em in as quick as thought.
column99: out with 'em from the heat,           They are brown and good to eat.
column100: [Illustration]           Now you think they've _paid the debt_!
column101: No, my friend, they're living yet.
column104: like two mice           Through their roofs they gnaw in a trice; [Illustration]           And the Baker cries, "You bet!
column106: *       *       *       *       *           This was the bad boys' sixth trick,           But the last will follow quick.
column108: I grow sick,           When I think on your last trick.
column109: [Illustration]           Why must these two scalawags           Cut those gashes in the bags?
column111: the farmer on his back           Carries corn off in a sack.
column112: [Illustration]           Scarce has he begun to travel,           When the corn runs out like gravel.
column113: [Illustration]           All at once he stops and cries:           "Darn it!
column116: with what delighted eyes           Max and Maurice he espies.
column118: he opens wide his sack,           Shoves the rogues in--Hukepack!
column119: [Illustration]           It grows warm with Max and Maurice,           For to mill the farmer hurries.
column122: Grind me _that_ as quick as you can!"
column124: Each wretched flopper           Headlong goes into the hopper.
column125: [Illustration]           As the farmer turns his back, he           Hears the mill go "creaky!
column127: [Illustration]           Here you see the bits _post mortem_,           Just as Fate was pleased to sort 'em.
column128: [Illustration]           Master Miller's ducks with speed           Gobbled up the coarse-grained feed.
column130: IN the village not a word,           Not a sign, of grief, was heard.
column131: Widow Tibbets, speaking low,           Said, "I thought it would be so!"
column133: Mischief is not life's true aim!"
column134: Then said gravely Teacher Laempel,           "There again is an example!"
column136: bad thing for youth,"           Said the Baker, "a sweet tooth!"
column138: See what comes of stupid jokes!"
column140: What concern is that to I?"
column141: Through the place in short there went           One wide murmur of content:           "God be praised!
column142: the town is free           From this great rascality!"

column394: [Illustration]           AH, how oft we read or hear of           Boys we almost stand in fear of!
column395: For example, take these stories           Of two youths, named Max and Maurice,           Who, instead of early turning           Their young minds to useful learning,           Often leered with horrid features           At their lessons and their teachers.
column396: Look now at the empty head: he           Is for mischief always ready.
column397: Teasing creatures, climbing fences,           Stealing apples, pears, and quinces,           Is, of course, a deal more pleasant,           And far easier for the present,           Than to sit in schools or churches,           Fixed like roosters on their perches.
column398: But O dear, O dear, O deary,           When the end comes sad and dreary!
column399: 'Tis a dreadful thing to tell           That on Max and Maurice fell!
column400: All they did this book rehearses,           Both in pictures and in verses.
column402: [Illustration]           TO most people who have leisure           Raising poultry gives great pleasure           First, because the eggs they lay us           For the care we take repay us;           Secondly, that now and then           We can dine on roasted hen;           Thirdly, of the hen's and goose's           Feathers men make various uses.
column403: Some folks like to rest their heads           In the night on feather beds.
column404: One of these was Widow Tibbets,           Whom the cut you see exhibits.
column405: [Illustration]           Hens were hers in number three,           And a cock of majesty.
column406: Max and Maurice took a view;           Fell to thinking what to do.
column408: as soon as said,           They have sliced a loaf of bread,           Cut each piece again in four,           Each a finger thick, no more.
column409: These to two cross-threads they tie,           Like a letter X they lie           In the widow's yard, with care           Stretched by those two rascals there.
column410: [Illustration] [Illustration]           Scarce the cock had seen the sight,           When he up and crew with might:           Cock-a-doodle-doodle-doo;--           Tack, tack, tack, the trio flew.
column411: [Illustration]           Cock and hens, like fowls unfed,           Gobbled each a piece of bread; [Illustration]           But they found, on taking thought,           Each of them was badly caught.
column412: [Illustration]           Every way they pull and twitch,           This strange cat's-cradle to unhitch; [Illustration]           Up into the air they fly,           Jiminee, O Jimini!
column413: [Illustration]           On a tree behold them dangling,           In the agony of strangling!
column414: And their necks grow long and longer,           And their groans grow strong and stronger.
column415: [Illustration]           Each lays quickly one egg more,           Then they cross to th' other shore.
column416: [Illustration]           Widow Tibbets in her chamber,           By these death-cries waked from slumber, [Illustration]           Rushes out with bodeful thought:           Heavens!
column418: [Illustration]           From her eyes the tears are streaming:           "Oh, my cares, my toil, my dreaming!
column419: Ah, life's fairest hope," says she,           "Hangs upon that apple-tree."
column420: [Illustration]           Heart-sick (you may well suppose),           For the carving-knife she goes;           Cuts the bodies from the bough,           Hanging cold and lifeless now           And in silence, bathed in tears,           Through her house-door disappears.
column421: [Illustration]           This was the bad boys' first trick,           But the second follows quick.
column423: WHEN the worthy Widow Tibbets           (Whom the cut below exhibits)           Had recovered, on the morrow,           From the dreadful shock of sorrow,           She (as soon as grief would let her           Think) began to think 'twere better           Just to take the dead, the dear ones           (Who in life were walking here once),           And in a still noonday hour           Them, well roasted, to devour.
column424: True, it did seem almost wicked,           When they lay so bare and naked,           Picked, and singed before the blaze,--           They that once in happier days,           In the yard or garden ground,           All day long went scratching round.
column426: Frau Tibbets wept anew,           And poor Spitz was with her, too.
column427: [Illustration] [Illustration]           Max and Maurice smelt the savor.
column430: [Illustration]           Through the chimney now, with pleasure,           They behold the tempting treasure,           Headless, in the pan there, lying,           Hissing, browning, steaming, frying.
column431: [Illustration]           At that moment down the cellar           (Dreaming not what soon befell her)           Widow Tibbets went for sour           Krout, which she would oft devour           With exceeding great desire           (Warmed a little at the fire).
column432: Up there on the roof, meanwhile,           They are doing things in style.
column433: Max already with forethought           A long fishing-line has brought.
column436: One hen dangling up the chimney.
column444: we have them all!--           Spitz looks on, we must allow,           But he barks: Row-wow!
column446: [Illustration]           But the rogues are down instanter           From the roof, and off they canter.--           Ha!
column447: I guess there'll be a humming;           Here's the Widow Tibbets coming!
column448: Rooted stood she to the spot,           When the pan her vision caught.
column453: Let me beat him black and blue!"
column455: Comes down on poor Spitz's back!
column456: Loud he yells with agony,           For he feels his conscience free.
column457: [Illustration]           Max and Maurice, dinner over,           In a hedge, snored under cover;           And of that great hen-feast now           Each has but a leg to show        *       *       *       *       *           This was now the second trick,           But the third will follow quick.
column459: THROUGH the town and country round           Was one Mr. Buck renowned.
column460: [Illustration]           Sunday coats, and week-day sack-coats,           Bob-tails, swallow-tails, and frock coats,           Gaiters, breeches, hunting-jackets;           Waistcoats, with commodious pockets,--           And other things, too long to mention,           Claimed Mr. Tailor Buck's attention.
column461: Or, if any thing wanted doing           In the way of darning, sewing,           Piecing, patching,--if a button           Needed to be fixed or put on,--           Any thing of any kind,           Anywhere, before, behind,--           Master Buck could do the same,           For it was his life's great aim.
column462: Therefore all the population           Held him high in estimation.
column463: Max and Maurice tried to invent           Ways to plague this worthy gent.
column464: Right before the Sartor's dwelling           Ran a swift stream, roaring, swelling.
column465: [Illustration]           This swift stream a bridge did span,           And the road across it ran.
column466: [Illustration]           Max and Maurice (naught could awe them!)
column467: Took a saw, when no one saw them:           Ritze-ratze!
column469: Sawed a gap across the middle.
column470: When this feat was finished well,           Suddenly was heard a yell: [Illustration]           "Hallo, there!
column475: Buck could bear all sorts of jeering,           Jibes and jokes in silence hearing;           But this insult roused such anger,           Nature couldn't stand it longer.
column476: [Illustration]           Wild with fury, up he started,           With his yard-stick out he darted;           For once more that frightful jeer,           "Muck!
column480: [Illustration]           On the bridge one leap he makes;           Crash!
column485: While the scared boys were skedaddling,           Down the brook two geese came paddling.
column486: [Illustration]           On the legs of these two geese,           With a death-clutch, Buck did seize; [Illustration]           And, with both geese _well in hand_,           Flutters out upon dry land.
column487: [Illustration]           For the rest he did not find           Things exactly to his mind.
column488: [Illustration]           Soon it proved poor Buck had brought a           Dreadful belly-ache from the water.
column490: She rises           Fully equal to the crisis;           With a hot flat-iron, she           Draws the cold out famously.
column491: [Illustration]           Soon 'twas in the mouths of men,           All through town: "Buck's up again!"
column492: *       *       *       *       *           This was the bad boys' third trick,           But the fourth will follow quick.
column494: AN old saw runs somewhat so:           Man must learn while here below.--           Not alone the A, B, C,           Raises man in dignity;           Not alone in reading, writing,           Reason finds a work inviting;           Not alone to solve the double           Rule of Three shall man take trouble:           But must hear with pleasure Sages           Teach the wisdom of the ages.
column495: [Illustration]           Of this wisdom an example           To the world was Master Lämpel.
column496: For this cause, to Max and Maurice           This man was the chief of horrors;           For a boy who loves bad tricks           Wisdom's friendship never seeks.
column497: With the clerical profession           Smoking always was a passion;           And this habit without question,           While it helps promote digestion,           Is a comfort no one can           Well begrudge a good old man,           When the day's vexations close,           And he sits to seek repose.--           Max and Maurice, flinty-hearted,           On another trick have started;           Thinking how they may attack a           Poor old man through his tobacco.
column498: Once, when Sunday morning breaking,           Pious hearts to gladness waking,           Poured its light where, in the temple,           At his organ sate Herr Lämpel, [Illustration]           These bad boys, for mischief ready,           Stole into the good man's study,           Where his darling meerschaum stands.
column499: This, Max holds in both his hands; [Illustration]           While young Maurice (scapegrace born!)
column500: Climbs, and gets the powderhorn,           And with speed the wicked soul           Pours the powder in the bowl.
column504: [Illustration]           Lämpel closes the church-door,           Glad to seek his home once more; [Illustration]           All his service well got through,           Takes his keys, and music too,           And his way, delighted, wends           Homeward to his silent friends.
column505: Full of gratitude he there           Lights his pipe, and takes his chair.
column507: he says, "no joy is found           Like contentment on earth's round!"
column511: The pipe is burst,           Almost shattered into dust.
column512: Coffee-pot and water-jug,           Snuff-box, ink-stand, tumbler, mug,           Table, stove, and easy-chair,           All are flying through the air           In a lightning-powder-flash,           With a most tremendous crash.
column513: [Illustration]           When the smoke-cloud lifts and clears,           Lämpel on his back appears;           God be praised!
column514: still breathing there,           Only somewhat worse for wear.
column515: [Illustration]           Nose, hands, eyebrows (once like yours),           Now are black as any Moor's;           Burned the last thin spear of hair,           And his pate is wholly bare.
column516: Who shall now the children guide,           Lead their steps to wisdom's side?
column517: Who shall now for Master Lämpel           Lead the service in the temple?
column518: Now that his old pipe is out,           Shattered, smashed, _gone up the spout_?
column519: [Illustration]           Time will heal the rest once more,           But the pipe's best days are o'er.
column520: *       *       *       *       *           This was the bad boys' fourth trick,           But the fifth will follow quick.
column522: IF, in village or in town,           You've an uncle settled down,           Always treat him courteously;           Uncle will be pleased thereby.
column524: Any errand I can do you?"
column525: Fetch whatever he may need,--           Pipe to smoke, and news to read;           Or should some confounded thing           Prick his back, or bite, or sting,           Nephew then will be near by,           Ready to his help to fly;           Or a pinch of snuff, maybe,           Sets him sneezing violently:           "Prosit!
column530: Or he comes home late, perchance:           Pull his boots off then at once,           Fetch his slippers and his cap,           And warm gown his limbs to wrap.
column531: Be your constant care, good boy,           What shall give your uncle joy.
column534: See now how they tried their wits--           These bad boys--on Uncle Fritz.
column535: What kind of a bird a May-           Bug was, _they_ knew, I dare say; [Illustration]           In the trees they may be found,           Flying, crawling, wriggling round.
column536: [Illustration]           Max and Maurice, great pains taking,           From a tree these bugs are shaking.
column537: [Illustration]           In their cornucopiæ papers,           They collect these pinching creepers.
column538: [Illustration]           Soon they are deposited           In the foot of uncle's bed!
column539: [Illustration]           With his peaked nightcap on,           Uncle Fritz to bed has gone;           Tucks the clothes in, shuts his eyes,           And in sweetest slumber lies.
column542: come the Tartars           Single file from their night quarters.
column543: [Illustration]           And the captain boldly goes           Straight at Uncle Fritzy's nose.
column547: [Illustration]           Uncle, wild with fright, upspringeth,           And the bedclothes from him flingeth.
column549: he seizes two more scape-           Graces from his shin and nape.
column550: [Illustration]           Crawling, flying, to and fro,           Round the buzzing rascals go.
column551: [Illustration]           Wild with fury, Uncle Fritz           Stamps and slashes them to bits.
column553: all gone by           Is the May bug's deviltry.
column554: [Illustration]           Uncle Fritz his eyes can close           Once again in sweet repose.

column557: EASTER days have come again,           When the pious baker men           Bake all sorts of sugar things,           Plum-cakes, ginger-cakes, and rings.
column558: Max and Maurice feel an ache           In their sweet-tooth for some cake.
column559: [Illustration]           But the Baker thoughtfully           Locks his shop, and takes the key.
column560: [Illustration]           Who would steal, then, _this_ must do:           Wriggle down the chimney-flue.

column563: Black as ravens, down the chimney.
